story:
We've passed our minimum goal but we're pushing through to the last minute of this campaign! Toya will use every dollar offered to support her healing. Please share this page and Toya's story, we are so grateful!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

UPDATE: Just a short time to go!!  Please join Team Toya and SHARE this campaign page so we can bring in as much support as possible -- sadly, Toya has been in a lot of pain the last couple weeks after a month or so of improvement. Every dollar helps her cover medical and living expenses during this difficult time. THANK YOU!

=============================================================

Toya has always been a fighter, a survivor. She is a loyal friend, a compassionate mentor, a creative force to be reckoned with. Now she needs our help for a challenging period of recovery from a painful spinal condition that has put her life on hold. We, her partner, family, and friends, have loved and helped Toya as best we can over the last three months, and we’re now reaching out to bring in more support to help her cross the finish line. The world needs Toya back to full strength and you can help her get there!

Toya’s Story

Since mid-April, Toya has been suffering from debilitating back pain, often hitting excruciating levels. An MRI eventually showed that she had a severely herniated lumbar disc causing significant inflammation, spinal stenosis, damage to neighboring vertebrae, and nerve impingement. What does that mean? PAIN. Pain in the lower back and radiating down the legs, making walking difficult to unbearable.

She’s spent most of the last three months in bed requiring help with basic needs, and using a wheelchair when she’s able to leave the house. Toya had to leave her job as a Physical Education Specialist at an afterschool program AND had to leave school two weeks before earning her Associate’s Degree in Early Childhood Education. Financially, she and her partner, Jen, have been struggling to cope with the loss of Toya's income during this time of increased needs.

Navigating the health system has been an all-consuming project for Toya and Jen. Toya has been to the ER three times while waiting to see various specialists who offered inconsistent advice and little relief. On June 21, Toya’s 28th birthday, she finally saw a highly recommended orthopedic surgeon who explained her condition more thoroughly and said she had been given poor advice and was on the wrong meds.

Toya had a microdiscectomy on July 3 - an outpatient surgery to remove the part of the disc that was impinging on the nerve and causing her pain (see the Gallery for an image of the MRI showing the ruptured disc). She has experienced some improvement since the surgery, but it could be weeks or months until her pain decreases to tolerable levels. Toya continues to require support while she recovers the ability to care for herself independently, return to work, and continue her education.

As frustrating as the situation has been, Toya is not despondent. Toya is a fighter! She is fully dedicated to her recovery and has thrown herself into the healing process.

Community & Recovery

Toya has cultivated a supportive and nurturing community in Albany which has risen up to help with house work, cooking, and errands during this difficult time. The road to recovery has already been longer than anticipated, and it is impossible for her partner and friends to keep up with the level of assistance required... and more costs still lie ahead.

Our minimum goal is to raise $7,500 to support Toya’s successful recovery! 

Your donation will help Toya with medical expenses not covered by insurance: physical therapy and assistive devices, complimentary treatments like acupuncture and massage, and transportation to appointments. Because she’s been out of work, Toya needs help covering basic needs like rent, utilities, phone bills, and food. She has also had to hire people to help her with daily activities while she recovers - both household help and getting out of the house. Every time she leaves home, she needs help walking and someone to carry her wheelchair down two flights of stairs. Jen does what she can but is nearly out of paid time off from work.

But there's more, because we want Toya not just to recover and survive, but to get back to thriving. We hope to raise $10,000. Toya will use the additional funds for things that improve her quality of life: art supplies and classes, a personal trainer to help her regain her strength and move her back toward her goal of running a 10k, and additional health and wellness needs. Any further donations will help Toya continue her college education towards her Bachelors degree in Physical Education.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to do more than just donate, or if you cannot make a donation at this time, please share this Indiegogo campaign with your Facebook community and email contacts. Toya is printing and mailing this request to relatives who don’t use the internet, and we’re happy to print copies for others. If you prefer to donate offline, please contact us.

Donate, get the word out, and help Toya get pain free, back on her feet, and out into the world where she will again be inspiring others with her love of life and drive to overcome! She can't wait to be back with "her kids" at the aftershool program and back to practicing her passion!

                                      THANK YOU!

Thank you in advance for your generosity! Every little bit helps. 

- Jen & everyone at "Team Toya"

 

Special thanks to Sean Desiree for creating the campaign video.

 

Curious about the specifics of Toya’s condition and surgery?

Here are some links to videos and additional information:

  • Herniated Discs: what the heck are they? videos:
    • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XmDAjM815gs -- helpful animation
    • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WXTdoXzWzwo- a doctor pointing to models of spine, shows the progression from healthy disc to bulge to herniation to rupture, all of which Toya went through
  •  About microdiscectomy surgery (scroll down a bit for video):
    • http://www.spine-health.com/treatment/back-surgery/microdiscectomy-microdecompression-spine-surgery
  • Toya’s surgeon: Dr. Robert Cheney - multiple nurses called him "eye candy," but all, thankfully, also agreed that he's very very good at what he does
    • http://www.capitalregionorthopaedics.com/about/physician-bios/robert-cheney-md
story_txt:
We've passed our minimum goal but we're pushing through to the last minute of this campaign! Toya will use every dollar offered to support her healing. Please share this page and Toya's story, we are so grateful!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
UPDATE: Just a short time to go!!  Please join Team Toya and SHARE this campaign page so we can bring in as much support as possible -- sadly, Toya has been in a lot of pain the last couple weeks after a month or so of improvement. Every dollar helps her cover medical and living expenses during this difficult time. THANK YOU!
=============================================================
Toya has always been a fighter, a survivor. She is a loyal friend, a compassionate mentor, a creative force to be reckoned with. Now she needs our help for a challenging period of recovery from a painful spinal condition that has put her life on hold. We, her partner, family, and friends, have loved and helped Toya as best we can over the last three months, and we’re now reaching out to bring in more support to help her cross the finish line. The world needs Toya back to full strength and you can help her get there!
Toya’s Story
Since mid-April, Toya has been suffering from debilitating back pain, often hitting excruciating levels. An MRI eventually showed that she had a severely herniated lumbar disc causing significant inflammation, spinal stenosis, damage to neighboring vertebrae, and nerve impingement. What does that mean? PAIN. Pain in the lower back and radiating down the legs, making walking difficult to unbearable. 
She’s spent most of the last three months in bed requiring help with basic needs, and using a wheelchair when she’s able to leave the house. Toya had to leave her job as a Physical Education Specialist at an afterschool program AND had to leave school two weeks before earning her Associate’s Degree in Early Childhood Education. Financially, she and her partner, Jen, have been struggling to cope with the loss of Toya's income during this time of increased needs.
Navigating the health system has been an all-consuming project for Toya and Jen. Toya has been to the ER three times while waiting to see various specialists who offered inconsistent advice and little relief. On June 21, Toya’s 28th birthday, she finally saw a highly recommended orthopedic surgeon who explained her condition more thoroughly and said she had been given poor advice and was on the wrong meds. 
Toya had a microdiscectomy on July 3 - an outpatient surgery to remove the part of the disc that was impinging on the nerve and causing her pain (see the Gallery for an image of the MRI showing the ruptured disc). She has experienced some improvement since the surgery, but it could be weeks or months until her pain decreases to tolerable levels. Toya continues to require support while she recovers the ability to care for herself independently, return to work, and continue her education.
As frustrating as the situation has been, Toya is not despondent. Toya is a fighter! She is fully dedicated to her recovery and has thrown herself into the healing process. 
Community & Recovery
Toya has cultivated a supportive and nurturing community in Albany which has risen up to help with house work, cooking, and errands during this difficult time. The road to recovery has already been longer than anticipated, and it is impossible for her partner and friends to keep up with the level of assistance required... and more costs still lie ahead.

Our minimum goal is to raise $7,500 to support Toya’s successful recovery! 

Your donation will help Toya with medical expenses not covered by insurance: physical therapy and assistive devices, complimentary treatments like acupuncture and massage, and transportation to appointments. Because she’s been out of work, Toya needs help covering basic needs like rent, utilities, phone bills, and food. She has also had to hire people to help her with daily activities while she recovers - both household help and getting out of the house. Every time she leaves home, she needs help walking and someone to carry her wheelchair down two flights of stairs. Jen does what she can but is nearly out of paid time off from work.
But there's more, because we want Toya not just to recover and survive, but to get back to thriving. We hope to raise $10,000. Toya will use the additional funds for things that improve her quality of life: art supplies and classes, a personal trainer to help her regain her strength and move her back toward her goal of running a 10k, and additional health and wellness needs. Any further donations will help Toya continue her college education towards her Bachelors degree in Physical Education.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you want to do more than just donate, or if you cannot make a donation at this time, please share this Indiegogo campaign with your Facebook community and email contacts. Toya is printing and mailing this request to relatives who don’t use the internet, and we’re happy to print copies for others. If you prefer to donate offline, please contact us.
Donate, get the word out, and help Toya get pain free, back on her feet, and out into the world where she will again be inspiring others with her love of life and drive to overcome! She can't wait to be back with "her kids" at the aftershool program and back to practicing her passion!
                                      THANK YOU!
Thank you in advance for your generosity! Every little bit helps. 
- Jen & everyone at "Team Toya"
 
Special thanks to Sean Desiree for creating the campaign video.
 
Curious about the specifics of Toya’s condition and surgery?
Here are some links to videos and additional information:


Herniated Discs: what the heck are they? videos:


http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XmDAjM815gs -- helpful animation

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WXTdoXzWzwo- a doctor pointing to models of spine, shows the progression from healthy disc to bulge to herniation to rupture, all of which Toya went through


 About microdiscectomy surgery (scroll down a bit for video):

http://www.spine-health.com/treatment/back-surgery/microdiscectomy-microdecompression-spine-surgery




Toya’s surgeon: Dr. Robert Cheney - multiple nurses called him "eye candy," but all, thankfully, also agreed that he's very very good at what he does

http://www.capitalregionorthopaedics.com/about/physician-bios/robert-cheney-md

story:
The Best Beach Towel for Tanning.

How often do you reposition your towel to catch the best rays? We love the beach and the sun and after fiddling around with our towels time and time again we decided it was too much!

Our Circle Towels eliminate the need to disrupt your tan schedule while ensuring your neighbor on the sand is comfortable too. Rotating your towel every hour is not only inconvenient for you, but it also makes sand blow all over your neighbors – especially when the wind takes control. Our over-sized beach towels offer the optimal environment for sunbathing. Unlike normal beach towels, our circle towels allow sunbathers to stretch out comfortably and not worry about the hot sand. The circular shape also allows for full rotation without the hassle of shifting your towel.

Quality You Can Count On - Comfort You Deserve.

 

Our towels are perfect for the beach, poolside or by any picnic table.  They are 100% cotton with a luxurious 6' radius.

The Idea came came to my Business partner Aaron more then a decade ago; I'll let him explain the story:

“I went to the beach wanting to relax but realized that I spent more time moving my towel and shaking off the sand then enjoying the peace and quiet. So I asked myself, why isn't there a circle towel that will put an end to this unnecessary moving and shaking? That’s when the idea came to me! That’s how The CircleTowel.com was born.”


The money raised on this Indiegogo campaign will help us with initial inventory and continue marketing of the site and the brand to help beachcombers, pool people and picnickers get more pleasure out of their day.



What We Need & What You Get

  • Ramping up manufacturing to produce a sufficient number of towels for broad distribution coast to coast is costly! We need funds to buy the raw materials, produce the towels in an ethical factory and produce the finished product.
  • Our Circle Towel is about as "outside the box" you can get so we need a good amount of funds on marketing and raising awareness of why our towels are better and why people will love them.
  • If we fall short of our full funding goal we'll make the best with what we have and produce as many towels as possible around a realistic marketing budget.
  • As a backer of our campaign you get the first crack at our towels with some of the lowest possible prices.


Risks & Challenges

As much as we wanted to produce the towel in the United States the cost was just too high. We found a great company in China that after many months, was finally able to produce The Circle Towel we were looking for. There are always some sort of delay with the final samples or shipping the product from China to the states but we have a great team in place to handle any challenges that may come up.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and tell all your friends, family and neighbors about our towels.  Use the Indiegogo share tools on this project and keep your Facebook friends and Twitter followers in the know.

story:
FUNDRAISER: BEATING CANCER

    This fundraiser is for Scott and his mother Marilyn who has terminal cancer. She has pancreatic cancer. She has been ill most of her life with various illnesses and is also a diabetic which has caused many other issues such as loss of mobility and sensation/feeling in her hands and feet. About two years ago, Scott took his mother to the doctor and after six months of appointments and scans, she learned she had pancreatic cancer on top of diabetes. She had underwent chemotherapy but was just recently told that it had spread to her stomach and lungs. She has not been given a time frame at this moment. Scott's biggest concern is the current medical bills that continue to mount and medication needed to improve the quality of his mother's life along with the household expenses. 
   Scott, being ill himself, is currently unable to work. He is the father of six children; with the youngest being less then one years old. He takes care of his family as well as taking care of his terminal mother too. The cost for aids for Marilyn, house bills, medical expenses and ultimately funeral cost are in the minds of Marilyn, Scott and his family.  Not only has medical gone up in price but the cost of living and unfortunately funeral cost have increased too. Scott has a lot on his plate. I applaud him for all that he does for his family and putting himself last. Not many would do what he is doing and I have the utmost respect and admiration for him. He is a strong man but even the strongest person is in need of a hand up. So I am asking for your help.
    We are in need of funding to help to pay for unpaid medical expenses, medication, and household bills like food, electric, gas, etc. and the expected funeral cost that is in the near future. Unfortunately Scott and his mother Marilyn are in this situation and time is not on their side.  And without those things, the quality of Marilyn's life will decrease and make things harder for his family. Life is hard enough without having to worry about how your going to pay your bills. With the proper care, medical attention, medication, and everyday living expenses paid, it will not extend the amount of time that Marilyn has left but it WILL increase the quality of her life and help Scott to improve on the quality of his families life too. I believe that quality outweighs quantity.
   Whether we reach our goal or not; whether it's $1000 or $10,000, it will make the quality of Marilyn's and Scott's  lives better from what it is now. 
   Life is full of love, happiness, pain and tears. But its what we do with that, that makes it count; that makes living worth while and makes those that you love and that love you back, that much more meaningful, heartfelt and deeper. It gives life the meaning that we all are in search of. Helping a stranger out and knowing that you are a blessing in the shadows.
   We all take life for granted. And it isn't until that moment, when you realize that you might loose something or someone, that you see how much that person, or thing (sight, voice, limb, home, etc.) means to you. 
   Blessings come in many forms. It may come in the form of a storm or from a persons generosity. Healing can come to you in tears or through a person's touch. Those sleepless nights and tears we shed are just reminders we are alive and we all have burdens to shoulder. I believe that the pain we feel is just a reminder that this world is not our final resting place. It's not our home. We have somewhere else that is  far better than where we are now. And all the suffering, tears, happiness and love, remind me of this daily; that this life is just a stepping stone to somewhere bigger and better without the trials, tribulations, heartaches and disappointments. Its a place of love, laughter, happiness and peacefulness. Its a place of giving and not receiving. Isn't this what we all want? Isn't this where we all want to be? God has a better place for us. And that is something I remind myself of and I am looking forward to. This isn't all of it. There is something bigger than me. Someone, bigger than me. God is waiting for me. And until my time, I will do what I can to improve myself and become a better person. In any way that the Lord has directed me to. 
   But while we are here, at this moment, in this place, why make it harder? Why not help those that need it? Why not give a little of yourself to someone else whether you know them or not? Isn't that what compassion and understanding is? Putting yourself in another person's shoes and walking where they have or are walking now? Ask yourself this...if I were in this situation or,  knew someone that was,  would you want or need help? Would you help them and wouldn't you want all the help you could get? Giving a hand up is an amazing feeling. It's satisfying and is good for the soul. Just to know that you have helped someone. That you may be that blessing in disguise (so to speak) that they needed. To be that person that is willing to lend a helping hand to someone you don't know while standing in the shadows not expecting anything in return except the knowledge that you have helped someone in need. Just the knowing is all the confirmation any of us need or want.
   I don't know Scott or his mother personally. I have only met Scott on Instagram. We are in the same groups and create the same type of art. We talk in our chat groups on LINE. When I found out that his mother had terminal cancer and that he was ill himself, I wanted to help, so I put this fundraiser together. With the generosity of many artist who have donated their work, they too have made this possible.  
   We don't have to know the person that we are helping. All we need to know is their story, their background, their need. All we need to do is listen, hear, understand and help. That is all I am asking of you. Please bless Marilyn, Scott and his family. 
   If you are unable to make a financial donation, please make a different donation in the form of a prayer. Please pray for peace, love, understanding, and time. Please pray for quality over quantity. Please pray for their protection, guidance, and for God to ease their pain. To put His healing hand upon their hearts and to help ease their burdens. 
   Another way you can help is donating a few minutes of your time by letting your friends and family know about Scott and Marilyn's story. So, if you can, help spread the word and make some noise regarding this campaign/fundraiser. 
PERKS/GIFT
{If you are able to donate, we are offering ONE (1) print for a donation of $50 - $100. You will get THREE (3) prints for donations of $150 - $225. You get FOUR (4) prints for all donations over $275. Please visit the 'Gallery' tab to view the prints that are available. The artist's name, the title of the print and contact information is under the artwork.}
I thank you for whatever you can do...whether it be a donation, spreading the word about this fundraiser or a saying a prayer. Everything counts. Everything matters. Everyone counts. Everyone matters.
God bless you all and peace and love be with you and yours.

With my heartfelt thanks and kindest respects,

Carole Reeves

A MESSAGE TO MY PEEPS:
   I also want to give a huge THANK YOU to Peta, Joanne and Suzanne for your help and assistance. You have been amazing! I am blessed to have met you three and you will always be in my prayers and in a special place that is reserved for special friends. I am grateful to you all. Thank you for your help and all the support. You have no idea how much you all mean. Thank you again.

story:
Ethan Roman

Ethan Roman was born on December 7, 2011 in Jacksonville Florida. He weighed in at 9lbs 5oz (a very big boy). His mom and I were engaged to be married and she and Ethan would travel back and forth between Florida and London constantly so we could all be together - in the meantime I have been going through the K1 fiance visa process for 2.5 years and cannot travel to the US until the process is completed.

Unfortunately, Ethan's mom was arrested a few weeks ago following an altercation with a friend and is now away for a while - her parental rights have been stripped by the court. Ethan has no family in the US that can take him and so he has been placed in the foster care system until either I can get out there or his mom is sufficiently rehabilitated to start the long process of getting him back. I was told by the judge that I 'am the only person that can get Ethan out of care now'! As you can imagine I am frantic.

The legal bills for this are astronomical and I just can't afford them. I have paid out pretty much everything and now I am short by £10,000 to pay the rest of the legal bills - there are trial lawyers, immigration lawyers, criminal lawyers - this is a mess and I was totally unprepared for all of it. I just try to remain focused on my son and getting him home.

Ethan is such a sweet boy. Well behaved and just so cute. Everybody loves him and his wry smile. Seeing him on a computer 3 times a week for 10 minutes each time is dragging me down to the point where I am finding it hard to concentrate, let alone work.

I need help - I need to get my son back. Unfortunately family aren't interested and I am stuck. This is for my son. Please help if you can; every little helps!

Should I surpass my target or not need the full amount raised, any extra money raised will be donated to the RSPCC.

What I need

I need to raise up to £10,000 to help pay for the legal bills I am incurring as a result of Ethan being placed in foster care in the US.

All monies raised will go exclusively toward the legal costs and will be transferred direct to my team of lawyers. Any extra or surplus money will be donated to the RSPCC.

The Impact

Ethan is in dire trouble. He is in the foster care system now and it could take months or even years to get him out if I can't get over there asap. If his mom goes to jail and I can't get there, he will be placed for adoption and I CANNOT LET THAT HAPPEN. He is the sweetest little boy and innocent in all of this.

Seeing him on a computer 3 times a week for 10 minutes each time is dragging me down to the point where I am finding it hard to concentrate, let alone work.I need help - I need to get my son back. Unfortunately family aren't interested and I am stuck. This is for my son. Please help if you can; every little helps!Should I surpass my target or not need the full amount raised, any extra money raised will be donated to the RSPCC.What I needI need to raise up to £10,000 to help pay for the legal bills I am incurring as a result of Ethan being placed in foster care in the US.All monies raised will go exclusively toward the legal costs and will be transferred direct to my team of lawyers. Any extra or surplus money will be donated to the RSPCC.The ImpactEthan is in dire trouble. He is in the foster care system now and it could take months or even years to get him out if I can't get over there asap. If his mom goes to jail and I can't get there, he will be placed for adoption and I CANNOT LET THAT HAPPEN. He is the sweetest little boy and innocent in all of this.

story:
Summary 

I'm Stella, and I'm a single mom to five lovely children ranging in age from 5 to 20.  I also happen to suffer from a progressive and terminal lung disease called Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, for which there are no proven treatments other than lung transplant, and sadly, no cure.  Because of my disease, my kids have been exposed to many things that other children don't have to deal with until much later in life, but contrary to what you may initially think? This isn't always a bad thing!  

My daughter is seventeen and coming up on her last year at home before she embarks on her college career, and she is very aware of the need for research where it concerns lung disease and potential treatments.  She's very active athletically in her high school, and when she heard of the Hustle up the Hancock and learned that the proceeds benefit respiratory health and lung reasearch, she immediately urged me to sign her up.  My youngest, the five year old, adores his older sister as only a baby brother can, and when he heard that she was going to run up to the top of that tall building, there was no way he was going to not make her take him along.

We are setting our goal at $2500, which covers the registration and fundraising fees for them both to participate in the Hustle up the Hancock on their very own team, which they have decided will be Team SuperStella.  The remainder (about $95) will go into my gas tank, to transport them to Chicago for the event.

What We Need 

Registration is open for teams, and we need $405 up front in order to register.  The remainder does not have to be raised until March, giving us a little more time and opportunity for fundraising. 

The fees and details about the Hustle up the Hancock can be found at Hustleupthehancock.org - We need $265 for Nellie, as the team captain, and $140 for Homer, as a Lung Health Chamion on Team SuperStella.

For more information about Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, the disease which has invaded my lungs (and our lives), please check out http://pulmonaryfibrosis.org/ 

For more information about the Respiratory Health Association, which benefits from the Hustle up the Hancock, please check out: http://www.lungchicago.org/

Every little bit helps, so even if you only have a few bucks sitting in your paypal, it adds up when put together with the few bucks from everyone else's paypals.  And if you can't give, you can still share on your facebook, twitter, tumblr, whatever works to get the word out.  We appreciate your help.

story:
Our Story started in 2008 but has grown and continued since.....

My husband (Steven) and I (Jessica) met in Kuwait while serving the US Army National Guard on a deployment. We fell in love and continued our life together in Massillon, OH. After we came home we wanted to expand our family a little more, we have a 7 year old daughter, Dakota. We went to numerous doctors appointments and were told it was a 1 in a million chance we would get pregnant on our own and if we did we would have to abort because it would be a tubal baby. We were told we couldn't get pregnant without infertility drugs. In Jan 2011 we found out we were pregnant all by God's grace and now we have identical twin boys that were born 9 weeks early on July 14th, 2011. Tanner Owen weighed 3lbs 15oz and our peanut Tyler Austin weighed 2lbs 7oz. It was a very high risk pregnancy and they worried we would even have our children alive. Our sons were born early because of Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome Stage 1, which means their amniotic fluid wasn't being shared equally because they were sharing the same placenta. They thought that Tanner has brain damage because of too little fluid and Tyler would have heart failure because of too much fluid. Tyler in the end was the one that was the most worried about. He has a rare disorder that 1 in 3,000-5,000 kids have when they are born called EA/TEF (Esophageal Atresia/Tracheoesophageal Fistula). This means that his esophagus was attached to his trachea by a fistula, allowing stomach acids to go into his lungs. He has now had 3 surgeries to remove fistulas and no has no bottom portion of his esophagus. He has had 3 more surgeries to remove part of his right lower lung because it was so badly damaged, put in a trach because he can't breath on his own, remove 2 hernias, put in 2 broviac IV lines, put in a G-tube because without his esophagus he can't eat like us, and many more procedures. He has to have at least one more surgery to have his esophagus rebuilt. He also has hypothroidism (low thyroid level) which puts him on lifelong meds, pulmonary hypertension, neonatal seizures, vertebrae anomally (wedged vertebrae), and Atrial Septal defect (hole in his heart on the atrial side). There could be more surgeries needed.

The Impact

We are raising this money to help get our little boy home and to pay for his medical bills. Right now Tyler will not be able to come home due to our home has electrical issues and some mold in our home. We have to fix these issues because he will be coming home on medical equipment to keep him alive. He will come home with his trach and a ventilator. These require a ventilator machine, a back up ventilator for power outages and traveling to and from doctors appointments, humidifier to provide him with humidified oxygen, oxygen concentrator, extra oxygen tanks for mobility, and his feeding machine. Since we live where its cold and power outages happen often we would like to purchase a generator for his medical equipment to stay on even through this. He has also racked up over $1,000,000 in just his first 5 months of life. Since he's in the hospital still currently fighting for his life, these bills will just become greater. If we do not recieve enough money to fix our home and bring home Tyler we could end up not being able to bring him home or may end up doing without necessities that are needed for the rest of our family for him to come home.


What We Need & What You Get

We need enough money for our Tyler to come home and still be able to afford to keep our home, food on the table and gas in our car to take him to and from the hospital. This may also help us to get any medical equipment and medication that Tyler may need that will not be covered by the insurance companies.

We wont be able to afford much to give to you. The money that is donated we would like to go to our Tyler as much as possible and getting him home. I know we can afford to send a Thank you Card with a picture of our family and if you send a generous donation we would be able to send you the TEF ribbon magnet we made for our Tyler to help spread awareness.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by spreading the awareness. We had no clue that Tyler had EA/TEF. We only found out because afte the boys were born they tried to put an NG (NasoGastric Tube) down his nose for feedings and it wouldn't go down because the top portion of his esophagus was only a few centimeters long. If you just make others aware of this disorder and to have pregnant women talk to their doctors about this disorder it could save many baby's lives.

You could also help by sharing this with others. Letting them know that we could use help. You could also show our blog to others. I have blogged about all the moments we have gone through since the boys were born on www.caringbridge.org/visit/tylertannertruesdale

story:
When we heard about the shooting at Sikh Temple in Wisconsin. We immediately thought of the family members of the shooting victims. And the pain they would have to endure in coming weeks and months. 

We felt sorry but wanted to do something for them. So thought of starting a fund for the families. Most of Sikh famiies are immigrants and any help we provide is going to ease their pain a little.

News Coverage

CNN - http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/us/sikh-temple-shooting/index.html

Additional Coverage by Sikh Media sites

http://www.sikhcoalition.org/

 

Google News (Multiple Sources)

http://news.google.com/news/rtc?pz=1&cf=all&topic=n&ncl=d9RIK7Zhwdj0RMMUYQcwdDv8idvDM

 

Help the shooting victims of the Sikh Temple Shooting at Wisconsin.

100% of the funds would be divided and delivered to family members to cover Funeral/ Transportation and Relocation costs.

And possibly help next to Kin to manage expenses in the aftermath of the shooting.

 

If we collect enough fund we will donate part of the funds to the Wisconsin Police Department. 

 

Thank you

****** UPDATE 8/5/2012 7:20pm ********

We pray for the Officer who got injured !!

story:
Amanda Hope’s Story   Our sweet, jovial little girl, Amanda, was 9 years old when she started experiencing severe headaches and flu-like symptoms. Our visits to the pediatrician all had the same outcomes - flu, stomach virus, possible anemia. Finally, just to appease me, her pediatrician pricked her finger. Amand...

a’s Hemoglobin was only 2.6, which couldn’t be, so he pricked her finger a second time and then a third. He could not believe it was that low so he ordered more blood drawn and sent us home stating he would call when the result where in. Within a few hours, I received a call from her doctor saying "Mrs. Tallman, I am sorry to tell you Amanda has leukemia and I have a room waiting for her at Phoenix Children’s Hospital. Our lives changed forever in that moment.   I was in shock and disbelief – never had Cancer entered my mind. I remember standing there thinking “Oh My God, there must be a mistake”. I called my husband, telling myself to breath, knowing I must keep it together because my sweet Amanda was just in the next room. I gathered some toys and her favorite blanket, gave her a big hug, and told her that Mommy had to take her to the hospital because her blood was sick and we needed more tests. She cried, “No Mommy, no more needles”. The next few weeks were excruciating because all our family and friends could do was pray for a miracle while we waited for more test results. It was confirmed. Amanda had an advanced form of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) and it would require 2½ years of Chemotherapy. And so our battle began.   Sadly, because Amanda's white blood cell counts were so low resulting in numerous infections, the majority of our first 18 months were spent in the hospital. The pain she suffered with endless hours of screaming is a memory I will have forever in my heart. Insane is the only word I can use for the side effects Amanda endured. She started getting stronger, laughing and smiling, our last 18 months being better than the first. Our brave Amanda withstood 3 long years of intense chemotherapy and we were in remission! To celebrate, we had a huge “No More Chemo Party” in March of 2011 that was attended by her family, friends, nurses, and doctors. It was the best day of my life! Amanda started school again with her friends, started back up with her karate lessons, built a Star Wars Lego Battleship with her sister, and found a passion for skateboarding and yoyos. Her “no more chemo” gift was an English Bulldog she named Bruiser who was just like his name! We had studied and looked at English Bulldogs for almost 2 years and he was her dream come true. Our life was finally at peace and I went back to work so we could start to pay off the debt associated with Amanda’s illness. Life was good! On June 23, 2011, Amanda came with me to work for “Bring Your Child to Work” day. She was having a great day; however, after lunch she started getting a headache saying "Mommy, I don't feel good at all." By 3:00pm, her pain had increased so I took her to her pediatrician who didn’t find anything and told us to take her home, give her Tylenol, and call if it worsens. About an hour later, the left side of Amanda’s face was paralyzed and she could not swallow. We rushed her to the hospital and our second nightmare began. After a crazy night of doctors, MRI’s, and CAT scans, they informed us she had a mass in her brain that required a biopsy. After hours of waiting, the surgeon came out and told us it looked like cancer and they were running tests on the biopsy. Our world of chemo and radiation began again. Amanda’s two sisters were tested to determine if they were candidates for a bone marrow transplant. Her oldest sister was a perfect match! New Hope. We spend our time preparing for transplant including receiving more chemo and radiation and another surgery to insert a Broviac® port intended for fluids, medications, and blood work during her transplant and recovery – so now we have a Broviac® and another port resulting in 8 to 10 IV lines running from her body almost daily. All this time she kept smiling, praying for other children, patting me on my back telling me “Mommy, everything's going to be okay”. We mourned the loss of her hospital friends along the way and celebrated with those who were still in remission.   A week before her scheduled transplant in January 2012, Amanda's cancer cells mutated. Chemo was like candy and we went from 0.05% cancer to 80% so she was no longer a candidate for transplant. Amanda never gave up hope and always believed in her healing. As one of her doctors said, “Amanda has more Mojo than I have ever seen before”! Amanda fought hard all while making everyone around her smile and laugh. She also had a dream. Amanda’s dream was that one day when she was healed she would make a clothing line for kids going through chemo that would allow them to keep their "modesty and dignity ". You see, Amanda always hated her body being exposed to a room full of strange doctors, nurses, and others and wanted better for other children.   On March 30, 2012, 11:29am, Amanda Hope lost her battle to Leukemia. Amanda Hope’s Vision: “Comfycozys for Chemo” These special T-shirts are designed with zippers, pockets and slits to allow access to chest-ports without exposing the child’s body and to allow for storing of the IV lines preventing tangling and pulling on their clothing. They are made in the fun, tie-dye colors that Amanda loved so much. Amanda’s spirit of life and integrity of self continues to inspire us all! Her dream is coming true. Five hundred children will receive “Comfycozys for Chemo” T-shirts this Christmas. By next Christmas, our goal is that every child in Arizona who needs a port will receive a “Comfycozys for Chemo” T-shirt from Amanda Hope's Dream. With God's blessing, please touch a child’s life today by supporting this amazing cause! Share Amanda Dream,If possible.. Please sponsor a child for 25.00
Please Share Amanda's story, we all know of someone that has battle Cancer. One day at a time, One life at a time we can all make a difference.
follow us: Lorrainetallman@comfycozy4chemo  or our facebook page:http://www.facebook.com/ComfycozysForChemo?ref=hl

story:
Short Summary

My name is Dionne W. Beauregard. I am President/CEO of VFMG Public Relations & Marketing, LLC, a Public Relations, Marketing and Events firm based inHouston, Texas. I hold a Bachelor Of Science in Criminal Justice and Social Science from the University of Houston and an M.B.A from the University of Phoenix. 

Over the years, we have continued to work very hard and to represent a diverse clientele base. Furthermore, I have mentored in the Big Brother Big Sister Program and I have been a member and Usher at Lakewood Church (Pastor Joel Osteen- Houston, Texas) for several years. It was important for me to incorporate the teachings of Pastor Joel Osteen into the everyday challenges of business while acting as a motivational force for my clients and colleagues. You can best believe, I will keep changing lives one vision at a time!!

VFMG has worked with many campaigns and are proud to note that the company will direct the majority of it's future efforts to making a difference in the world by extending a helping hand.

The Campaign

After learning about this horrific accident, I had to offer my services. Taquia, Drakori's mother needed assistance and a hope to believe that her child (1 of 4 children) would regain a normal life.  In my heart, I knew that anyone could be healthy one day and the next day we could all be fighting for our lives.  I am praying and asking each contributor to read our story and to know that the blessing that is given will assist this family for many years to come. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for small and large contributions to reach our goal. Due to the continued rising cost of healthcare, it is our prayer that we far exceed the goal. Drakori's medical bills have increased. He was released from the hospital however, he will require ongoing health treatments to ensure a 100% full recovery. Drakori's recovery process may take many years. 

The Impact

The VFMG Team is committed and will continue to assist this family in getting the word out for many years to come. Your kindness and generosity is important to this family. $1 can make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have a Twitter, Facebook, and Email, PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD. PLEASE USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS.

PRESS RELEASE

Contact: Dionne Beauregard

             Publicist          

             VFMG Public Relations & Marketing, LLC               

                 Tel. (832) 483-3350  *Email:visionfaithpr@yahoo.com

 

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Graduate survives car accident and coma and is finally able to walk to receive high school diploma.

If you don't believe in miracles, then you will have to keep reading!!

 
 
Drakori Murphy during a rehabilitation session.
PRLog (Press Release) - Aug 15, 2012
DALLAS, TX, August 14, 2012 – If you don't believe in miracles then you will have to keep on reading. On Thursday, August 16th, 2012, a miracle will take place. Eighteen year old Darkori Jovaughn Murphy (Kori for short) will finally be able to do something that few graduates think about.. to walk across the stage and to finally receive his well-deserved high school diploma. It has been a long road leading up to this big day!  

With much persistence and the desire to be better than he was before, on Thursday, August 16, 2012, at 6:30 PM, Drakori Murphy will officially receive his high school diploma from Cedar Hill High School -Performing Arts Center (1 Longhorn Blvd Cedar Hill, TX 75104). The first time around, the family celebrated his big day in the ICU at Baylor with the nurses and staff while he was still in a coma.  This time, Drakori is honored to share his even BIGGER day with everyone as he continue’s to get stronger each day.

On May 19, 2012, the day of his prom, Murphy was one of 3 passengers involved in a fatal car accident that killed his friend, Cornelius Towns, 18, of DeSoto, Texas,.   The 1994 Lexus driven by Evan Thomas Williams, 19, of Cedar Hill drifted off of the roadway, travelled down a grassy embankment on I-20 (Grand Prairie, Texas). 

The car became airborne and  travelled some distance before crashing.  Darkori, who was a front seat passenger was pulled out by Williams.

Murphy was airlifted to Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas and was in critical condition. Towns and Murphy were seniors at Cedar Hill High School.  Unfortunately, It has been a long road to recovery. Murphy has had to learn how to eat, walk, and to speak again. Taquia Murphy, Darkori’s mother stated, ”that he only had a 10% chance of recovery, and that the situation had been difficult for the family due to his mounting medical bills”.  That day family and friends filled up 2 floors and immediately began to pray.  The prognosis was dire: collapsed lungs, failing kidneys, a broken right leg and left collar bone. Kori was diagnosed with severe traumatic brain injury,with blood & fluid on the brain. Kori had blood transfusions, plastic surgery and a titanium rod inserted in his right leg to replace his crushed right femur bone.

But Takiyah, Darkori's mother, never doubted Kori would live, attributing her strength to faith in God and a host of family and friends (Brent, Willie Murphy,Reginald Thomas, Krandel and Anna Newton, Rev. Clenard and Rosalind Holmes, and Christopher Hawkins, Sr to name a few.) She said, “God just wanted our attention, so they continued to pray with thousands around the country who read Kori's story on Facebook, Twitter, the internet and by word of mouth.

Donavon Murphy, Kori's older brother decided to extend his stay in Texas ( Howard University student) just in case his little brother woke up and needed him. Kori's cousin and best friend, Karrington Ford, also a graduating senior this year, selflessly spent his entire summer helping the team of parents and grandparents care for his cousin. 

Kori is one of four children. His sisters Armani and Maiya Murphy as well as Alex Ellis kept Kori entertained by reading to him during his coma and giving him manicures.  The family camped out in the Baylor ICU and BIR, with the parents continued taking turns to spend the night with Kori. 

The Miracle

As the hours and days passed, Kori began to defy what the doctors had told the family, with few setbacks. Takiyah said, " It was like the more people began to pray in earnest, God began to heal Kori faster. I have had the best spiritual journey. Having such a supportive family made the tough days bearable and the good days great."

The family credits Kori's neurosurgeon, Dr. Doughty, and the ICU team of nurses, respiratory techs, all of which, the family believes were chosen by God to heal Darkori. Kori was in the ICU for 3 weeks before moving on to the Baylor Institute for Rehabilitation in Dallas, under the leadership of Dr. Dubiel and her team.

An avid Graphic Designer, before the accident, Drakori started a clothing line called, FromMeIIYou.  Entrepreneurship has always been a dream of his. He hopes that he can have a full recovery so that he can fulfill his dream. Lost in the accident was his beloved I-Phone 4, computer and his favorite Polo shirt.  We can rest assure that he will be back on top!!
                                                #  #   #

Dionne Beauregard, President/CEO of VFMG Public Relations & Marketing has setup a donation campaign called: 

The Darkori Murphy Recovery Campaign Fund on the website
 
Indiegogo.com
http://www.indiegogo.com/Thedarkorimurphyrecoverycampaign 
 
Video Footage of Car Accident
http://grandprairiereporter.com/blog1/2012/05/cedar_hill_high_school_senior.html 

The Big Day                                                                         
What:    High School Graduation
When:    Thursday, August 16, 2012
Time:    6:30 PM
Where:    Cedar Hill High School- Performing Arts Center
       1 Longhorn Blvd Cedar Hill, TX 75104
**************************************************************
For Interview availability & Donations to The Darkori Murphy Recovery Campaign Fund: 
Contact -Dionne Beauregard - VFMG Public Relations & Marketing, LLC
Phone:   (832) 483-3350
Email:      visionfaithpr@ yahoo.com
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Dionne W. Beauregard. I am President/CEO of VFMG Public Relations & Marketing, LLC, a Public Relations, Marketing and Events firm based inHouston, Texas. I hold a Bachelor Of Science in Criminal Justice and Social Science from the University of Houston and an M.B.A from the University of Phoenix. 
Over the years, we have continued to work very hard and to represent a diverse clientele base. Furthermore, I have mentored in the Big Brother Big Sister Program and I have been a member and Usher at Lakewood Church (Pastor Joel Osteen- Houston, Texas) for several years. It was important for me to incorporate the teachings of Pastor Joel Osteen into the everyday challenges of business while acting as a motivational force for my clients and colleagues. You can best believe, I will keep changing lives one vision at a time!!
VFMG has worked with many campaigns and are proud to note that the company will direct the majority of it's future efforts to making a difference in the world by extending a helping hand.
The Campaign
After learning about this horrific accident, I had to offer my services. Taquia, Drakori's mother needed assistance and a hope to believe that her child (1 of 4 children) would regain a normal life.  In my heart, I knew that anyone could be healthy one day and the next day we could all be fighting for our lives.  I am praying and asking each contributor to read our story and to know that the blessing that is given will assist this family for many years to come. 


What We Need & What You Get
We are asking for small and large contributions to reach our goal. Due to the continued rising cost of healthcare, it is our prayer that we far exceed the goal. Drakori's medical bills have increased. He was released from the hospital however, he will require ongoing health treatments to ensure a 100% full recovery. Drakori's recovery process may take many years. 


The Impact
The VFMG Team is committed and will continue to assist this family in getting the word out for many years to come. Your kindness and generosity is important to this family. $1 can make a difference.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you have a Twitter, Facebook, and Email, PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD. PLEASE USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS.
PRESS RELEASE
Contact: Dionne Beauregard
             Publicist          
             VFMG Public Relations & Marketing, LLC               
                 Tel. (832) 483-3350  *Email:visionfaithpr@yahoo.com
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

story:
THANK YOU to all of our donors to helping us reach our goal!

The campaign continues at Tom's personal fundraising website:
goo.gl/G6Y41B

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 

There is still and always a need for help to both our causes so PLEASE continue donating!

Delta Tau Delta Fraternity of GW is hosting a tailgate-inspired Philanthropy Week from September 24th-28th, known as "Delt's Tau-Gate."  We are putting on a variety of fun events on campus, and are hoping to count on the support of our family and friends in D.C. and around the country.  This year we chose two causes very close to our hearts.  ALL of the money raised through this fundraiser, which is overseen by our National Organization, will be going directly to our two causes.  Half of all proceeds will be donated to Tom Syron's medical expenses, a four-time cancer fighter and father of one of our own brothers.  The other half will be donated to the Katie Moore Foundation, an organization that funds research for rare cancer treatments.  Please consider donating, sharing this page, and supporting the fraternity's philanthropic efforts, the Syron family, and our surrounding community!

SORORITIES: Please donate using your organization's "perk" on the right sidebar.  Check the bottom of this page for point updates!!!! Good luck! 
Click HERE to send an email to friends and family!!

Tom Syron
YOU CAN HELP TOM AND HIS FAMILY IN A BIG WAY.
Working has became difficult for Tom while fighting cancer.  Between getting sick and receiving chemo treatments every other week, the family is struggling to pay for his increasing health Insurance, mortgage payments, and Medical Bills.  With the family's medical debts ever-increasing, any small amount helps. 
Our goal is to help Tom so that he does not need to worry about BILLS or the need to work during this struggling time.  Any financial contributions will allow Tom to focus on his physical health so that he can get stronger and be here with his family for years to come.  

The Katie Moore Foundation

1 in 4 people with cancer have a rare cancer.
Visit the KMF Website

The Katie Moore Foundation helps patients and families dealing with rare cancers through research, advocacy, and community.

While there is clearly a need for more research and improved treatments for common cancers, much progress has been made in recent years. This progress has been due to interest and funding from several sources. Common cancers affect many people; thankfully government funding from the National Cancer Institute is available to research these cancers. In addition, because there are many patients to study, academic centers have an easier time performing research. Common cancers are also an area that attracts research and development funding from pharmaceutical companies, who need to be sure that there is potential for a marketable product before they commit their resources. Private funding, from patients, families, and friends also makes a difference.

Rare cancers have none of these advantages. They are not a public health hazard, and government funding is not readily available. It is more challenging for academic institutions to perform research on small numbers of patients. Pharmaceutical companies are wary of developing products that might be used by only a handful of people. And there are not as many patients and families to raise awareness.  But a little known fact is that 1 in 4 people with cancer are suffering with a rare cancer.

Ironically, rare cancers may also be among the most treatable. We already know that some of these cancers have a very specific cause that can be effectively targeted with the right treatment. Examples include gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST), or acute promyelocytic leukemia, both which are caused by specific molecular alterations that can be successfully treated with  molecularly targeted therapies.

Katie Moore Foundation will seek to expand the scientific understanding of rare cancers and the set of clinical approaches available for treating them effectively.

You

  • Your gracious dollar not only goes towards directly helping Tom, but has a long-term impact in tackling and overcoming rare cancers through the Katie Moore Foundation.
  • Progress towards future treatments is only possible through generous individual donors, particularly since rare cancer research typically receives less funding, but is equally devastating.
  • If you cannot donate, please share this campaign to friends, family, or coworkers to make an impact .
Please contribute today

story:
InspireInYou was created to dramatically change the way people view and treat mental health around the world. 



InspireInYou is the Pandora Internet Radio for self-help, well being, motivation, counseling and therapy. Users are gauged on different criteria that identifies their mood, cognitive triggers, and mental health state. Then, our software matches each user to audio content tailored to each users specific needs. Channels are created for each user that focus on each area of improvement the user wishes to pursue. The audio content comes from  motivational speakers, clergy, counselors, psychologists, therapists and life coaches. 

We are set to launch in October.


InspireInYou can be accessed via phone application, desktop or any tablet device. Because of its versatility, groups such as active duty military and veterans will be able to access help for their issues anywhere they have an internet connection.  Our software service offers the option for complete anonymity to seek help. Users will never have to worry about someone identifying them with the problems they are trying to overcome. Those silent wounds some people suffer will begin to heal on the users own terms. 
Access will be available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. In addition to increasing access to mental health help, InspireInYou will eliminate negative stigmas that often push people away from getting the help they need.
With your help, we will scale our platform, further develop our software, and increase our marketing to get the word out to people who need our help. We want to offer help to people in all walks of life who are suffering from all types of issues. It is our desire to see people live to their full potential and become truly happy. 
With your contribution, you help us get one step closer to helping people thrive naturally! 
I want to thank everyone for donating, every dolalr helps! For those that love what we are trying to accomplish but can't donate, you can still help! Spread the word about us and leet everyone know!
Thank you!

story:
My name is John Polnik and I am a 70 year-old, retired tool maker currently residing in Kingman, AZ. 

In 2006 I was diagnosed with prostate and colon cancer. After twenty-five radiation treatments, surgeries, and numerous operations I am proud to say that I am a survivor.

Unfortunately, my life was forever changed since I was now subjected to the indignity of dealing with leakage from both my urostomy and colostomy bags.  The problem stemmed from the method used for securing the adhesive skin barrier which acts as buffer between the bag and your body. The commonly practiced method consists of pressing an awkward, donut-sized sticker around the stoma with your fingers. It was almost impossible for me to achieve a flush, airtight seal in this fashion and without that seal, leakage resulted. So I searched and searched for an applicator. It turned out that the product I was searching for simply did not exist.  It seemed that living with the anxiety of worrying about leakage and never feeling comfortable about leaving my house would ever end.  That is when I decided to utilize my skills to create a universal skin barrier applicator which would allow me to live a fuller and more natural lifestyle.  Today, I am proud to say it works and I currently have a U.S. Patent pending on my device - The Ostomy On.

My dream now is to market this product to the millions of people worldwide who are currently suffering as I once did.  The research is staggering.  The most common complaint amongst ostomy bag users is leakage, not from the bag, but from the adhesive skin barrier which acts as a buffer between the users skin and the bag. 

The Ostomy On can end the suffering of so many people and change their lives just as it changed mine, but I need help getting it to them.  I am writing to the IndieGoGo community today in hopes that I can perhaps find the funding and/or resources to help the millions of people that survived cancer only to find that they are virtual shut-ins because they do not have access to my product.  Please help me to help them.  I thank you for your time and consideration. 

Sincerely,

John Polnik

story:
The Story Behind CareerHub

CareerHub was created by Kim Coulthurst and Amanda Gerrie of Pathways Consultants, a Workforce Development consulting firm in the San Francisco Bay Area. With over 45 years of experience, we hear every day about the struggles of workforce professionals to verify employment.

Our motivation for CareerHub includes not only a desire to secure more accurate employment data, but to also move the field to embrace new modes of service (virtual coaching, case management, training and more).

By supporting CareerHub, you will make workforce professionals' jobs easier and, help people achieve their educational and career goals!


We Can't Do It Alone

We are raising $10,000  to:

  • Hire a marketing/customer service professional to help us get the word out about the importance and potential of CareerHub.
  • Continue to make improvements and updates to CareerHub so it works for you, the user. 
Be a Community Partner in CareerHub!  Perks for contributing to CareerHub include:
  • Digital gift cards via CareerHub
  • CareerHub t-shirt
  • Your name listed as a Founder on the CareerHub website
  • Coaching from the Pathways team


    Verify Employment and Keep Clients Engaged

    Service providers who help students and job seekers return to the labor market often struggle to determine the impact of their work.
    • CareerHub is an easy technological solution to help service providers connect with students and clients, and motivate them to stay in touch.

    Use CareerHub's automated system to VERIFY EMPLOYMENT with the click of a button:


    Send texts, voice and emails to one or many clients:


    Mobile technology has been proven to be an engaging, easy and cost-efficient way to  connect with clients, provide educational support, activity/event reminders, important messages to motivate and inspire clients.           In fact, we are designing and piloting a virtual service provision model with support from the CA WIB with 2 fantastic community partners in Contra Costa County, Opportunity Junction and Bay Area Community Resources, and our evaluation partner jdcPartnerships.


    Are We Crazy or Just Creative?

    As a small, woman-owned business of non-techies, we hesitated to break into unknown territory by building a technological solution to a human challenge.

    • We partnered with seasoned engineers, software developers and designers  . . . we speak tech.  Phase 1 is complete (text) and we are on to Phase 2:  voice and email.
    • We have independently financed 90% of the development of CareerHub. We are looking for your support to take it to the finish line!

    Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Get the word out about our campaign by sharing with friends and colleagues
    • Be a early adopter by signing up and using CareerHub at careerhubus.com STARTING DECEMBER 1
    • Help us by lending us your skills: graphic design, marketing, social media, software development, videography. We need it all!
story_txt:
The Story Behind CareerHub 
CareerHub was created by Kim Coulthurst and Amanda Gerrie of Pathways Consultants, a Workforce Development consulting firm in the San Francisco Bay Area. With over 45 years of experience, we hear every day about the struggles of workforce professionals to verify employment.
Our motivation for CareerHub includes not only a desire to secure more accurate employment data, but to also move the field to embrace new modes of service (virtual coaching, case management, training and more).
By supporting CareerHub, you will make workforce professionals' jobs easier and, help people achieve their educational and career goals!

  We Can't Do It Alone We are raising $10,000  to: 
Hire a marketing/customer service professional to help us get the word out about the importance and potential of CareerHub.
Continue to make improvements and updates to CareerHub so it works for you, the user.

Are We Crazy or Just Creative?  As a small, woman-owned business of non-techies, we hesitated to break into unknown territory by building a technological solution to a human challenge.

story:
Our Story

Bono was hospitalized twice just after his 3rd birthday in August 2011 and diagnosed with Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis. He was already being treated for Sensory Processing Disorder and was getting therapy 2 times a week. Being raised by a single mother, this put a major financial burder on them. He receives IV infusions every other week at the childrens hospital which takes about 4 hours on average.  He also has to have extra therapies and activities to keep his joints from stiffening. On Thanksgiving, his grandfather was lost to a tragic death by suicide. Being that his mom worked in sales, this too affected them financially. He takes over 30 doses of medication weekly including chemotherapy.  Although his mom thought the worst of their bad luck was over, she was recently fired for taking too much time to care for little Bono.  The family car is in dire need of repairs and that is the transportation to get Bono back and forth to his appointments, therapies and hospital visits.


The Impact

The help that we receive will help us maintain our home, prevent foreclosure & hopefully afford repairs on our truck to make it safe for Bono.


What We Need & What You Get

Any money at all will go directly to the financial problems that will help us remain in our home. It will only go towards the home and car situation .  For any that live in the South Florida area, donations of over 100.00 will entitle you to a free 1 hour photo shoot on location in the Broward area.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our plea for help with others. Every little bit helps & we thank you for reading and sharing!!

story:
A group of friends from Angeles City, Philippines are leading a lifetime project, a special one... to save and sustain the life of one dear friend...

WHO IS TAL?

Crystaleen Antonio, "Tal" to her close friends and family, is a 30-year old single mom, working as a public school teacher at Angeles City College in the Philippines. Tal was diagnosed with renal failure last November 2013. At the moment, her kidney function remains at a critical level of only 14%. After 3 separate medical opinions; the doctors recommended that she undergo a kidney transplant within the next 6 months.

WHY TAL NEEDS OUR HELP?

The reality is Tal’s salary as a public school teacher at USD$450 a month, is not even enough to cover her monthly medication and her basic needs so the cost of the kidney transplant is too overwhelming for her and her family.

The cost of the transplant operation, medication and hospitalization for 6 months post-transplant is estimated to reach USD $40,000. This amount does not cover daily living expenses to cover her basic needs.

Without a kidney donor, this amount will definitely be higher and the process will be longer. The good news is Tal has a willing donor, her eldest brother. The next step is for her to start the work-up procedures to test if her brother’s kidney will match. This process however, will only start once Tal can show to the National Kidney and Transplant Institute (Philippines) that she has USD $4,700 in her bank account.

HOW IS SHE NOW?

Tal is still able to live normally. She still goes to work daily at the City College of Angeles and she can still perform daily tasks independently. However, her physical activities and food intake are limited and must be regulated. She requires monthly medication amounting to USD $520 a month until she is able to afford a transplant.

WHERE WILL THE FUNDS GO?

Assuming Tal is able to raise enough money for transplant in the next 4 months, below is the quotation given to her. The amount will cover medication for 4 months before transplant, transplant cost and medication cost for 6 months after transplant. The amount below does not include additional cost after the 6th month…

SUMMARY OF TOTAL EXPENSES

USD 1 = PHP 42

A.  Estimated Expense for Kidney Transplant with Monoclonal Induction: PHP 705,000

B.  Medication: PHP 979,077

C.  Tests: PHP 10,000

Estimated Total: PHP 1,694,077 (USD $ 40,335)

Breakdown of expenses, pre and post the transplant

A. Kidney Transplant with Monoclonal Induction
A. Recipient Work-up
Laboratory Tests including PRA Screening and HLA Typing, PHP 72,700
Radiology, PHP 2,990
Cardiovascular, PHP 5,310
Sub-Total: PHP 81,000
B. Donor Work-up
Laboratory Tests including HLA Typing, PHP 41,180
Radiology including CT Angiogram, PHP 15,010
Cardiovascular, PHP 5,310
Nuclear Medicine, PHP 2,500
Sub-Total: PHP 64,000
C. Transplant Operation
Patient Operation with Monoclonal, PHP 380,000
Donor Nephrectomy (Laparoscopic), PHP 105,000
Open Surgery, PHP 75,000
Sub-Total: PHP 560,000

B. Medication
Daily medicines, before transplant
1. Ketobest, 6x daily, PHP 35 / tablet
2. Amlooipine (*), once daily, PHP 35 / tablet UPDATED PHP 14 
3. Metoprolol, twice daily, PHP 5 / tablet UPDATED PHP 4.15
4. Hemovin, once daily, PHP 12 / tablet
5. Sodium Bicarbonate (*), 3x daily, PHP 10 UPDATED PHP .60
6. Renvela, twice daily, PHP 60 / tablet UPDATED PHP 87 
7. Recormon, once a week, PHP 1,300 / injection- UPDATED PHP 1,759
8. Atorvastatin, once daily, PHP 35 / tablet UPDATED PHP 39 
(*) Cost, to be confirmed

Daily Amount required: PHP 638
Monthly Amount required: PHP 19,769
Total expense, during the 4-month period before the transplant: PHP 79,077

Medicines, after transplant
Monthly medication, for 6 months - including hospital bills and check-up: PHP 150,000 monthly
Total for 6 months: PHP 900,000

C. Tests
Check-up, minimum once a month, PHP 500
Laboratory tests, minimum once a month, PHP 2,000
Total monthly expense: PHP 2,500
Total expense, during the 4-month period before the transplant: PHP 10,000

We are reaching out to your kind hearts to support this cause and lend financial help to Tal. Even a small amount will help save and extend her life...Thank you very much.

story:
Peace Care


Peace Care, a nonprofit organization that cultivates collaborative, community-level global health solutions, will be continuing its pilot project in Senegal, West Africa that focuses on providing preventive services for cervical cancer in the healthcare system. A team from the University of Illinois at Chicago Department of Family Medicine travels twice yearly for this project.  

Through a novel approach with a Peace Corps partnership, this Peace Care project fosters collaboration between the health region of Kedougou, Senegal and the University of Illinois at Chicago to improve health care delivery within the local existing health care system as well as provides training in global health and cultural competency for U.S. health care trainees.

cost-effective interventions

The average cost of didactic materials for training a health worker in cervical cancer preventive services is about $150.  Whereas $3000 will pay for experiential / practical learning for 10 health workers.  As well, $300 funds a single day cervical cancer mass screening in a community (with about 15 to 20 women being screened) and $75 helps us provide a single clinic with the equipment necessary to screen for cervical cancer.

All contributions go to on-the-ground costs and any small contribution will go a long way.

impact

We are expanding our efforts to institute Cervical Cancer Preventive Services in rural Senegal where none previously existed.  Current estimates indicate that every year 1197 women in Senegal are diagnosed with cervical cancer and 795 die from the disease. Cervical cancer ranks as the most frequent cancer among women in Senegal, and is the most frequent cancer among women between 15 and 44 years of age.  

how you can help

Any litle bit counts, donate $1 dollar and spread the word. No amount will go unnoticed. Please post on your facebook, twitter and tell all of your friends!

Most of us know someone who has been impacted by Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) or by cervical cancer, it is an illness that touches women worldwide. Every woman deserves a chance to take their health into their own hands and get tested.

http://www.peacecare.org

http://peacecareworld.blogspot.com

http://www.facebook.com/peacecare.org
